newsitem.title: EL SALVADOR: Central American GDP growth seen at 4.6 pct in '97.
newsitem.headline: Central American GDP growth seen at 4.6 pct in '97.

text.p: The gross domestic product in five Central American countries is expected to grow by an average of 4.6 percent this year, up from 2.6 percent in 1996, the Central Reserve Bank of El Salvador said on Friday.
"An average growth of 4.6 percent is estimated, higher than the 2.6 percent registered in 1996," a bank report said.
The report considered the outputs of El Salvador, Guatemala, Costa Rica, Honduras and Nicaragua.
Meanwhile, inflation in the five countries is seen falling to 10.6 percent this year from 14.1 percent in 1996.
The report did not provide individual estimates of GDP and inflation for each country.
The report said the end of Guatemala's civil war "makes an economic recovery possible." The Guatemalan government and leftist rebels signed a peace treaty on December 29, ending 36 years of war.
In Costa Rica, the "adequate handling of the fiscal deficit and greater foreign investment have energized the economy," the report said.
"In El Salvador, the econonomic indicators reflect that the country has overcome the low economic cycle and internationally is seen as an attractive place for investment," the report said.
